transcripts.text: This is New York Senator Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.  This is a common household garbage disposal.  Apparently, the two have never met.

Alexandria Cortez, better known by her social media handle AOC, has been a bold political voice since becoming the youngest congresswoman in U.S.  history.  She's perhaps most noteworthy for authoring the Green New Deal.  This bill proposes the introduction of $12 trillion worth of new punitive taxes and regulations in the American economy, in an aim to help curb the  U.S.'s  contribution to the global climate crisis.  The radical measures have been estimated to yield an aggregate cost of $93 trillion.  To put that into better perspective, that's $600,000 per U.S.  household.  Also slated for demise are all those capitalistic perks we have to give up, such as basic air travel, two-day shipping, most supermarket produce, and probably more.

Despite lobbying for this hyper-aggressive tax on pretty much the entire country, many people praise Senator Cortez for her humble upbringing in Bronx, New York, translating to what many see as a relatability to the working class.
Last month, AOC took to Instagram Live to showcase herself building IKEA furniture in her new apartment.

To her credit, this is more believable than Elizabeth Warren cracking open a cold one with the boys, or Kamala Harris baking her mac and cheese.  But, like any politician, she's bound to have some gaffes.
Most recently, AOC shared her first encounter with a garbage disposal, describing it as terrifying.

made that noise and it scared the daylights out of me.  I am told this is a garbage disposal.  I've never seen a garbage disposal.  I never had one in any place I've ever lived.  It is terrifying.  I don't know what to use it for or what its purpose is.

To many of us, this is a basic kitchen appliance.  Invented in 1927 by John W. Hams, the garbage disposal sought to solve a major problem.  Prior to this innovation, many households had food scraps that would linger around.  This would cause clogged plumbing, smell, and pests.  The ability to grind this waste and do away with it at the sink right after food prep seemed like a natural upgrade.  But Senator Cortez's concerns seemed completely to miss the practical value households gained from garbage disposals.  Instead, she improperly assumed this machine, because of energy consumption, was potentially harmful to the environment and should be.
